pullRequest.body:
Define ordinal approximants for the least/greatest fixed points of a monotone function in a complete lattice. It is sometimes also called the constructive Knaster-Tarski Theorem, first introduced by Cousot & Cousot in 1979. This implementation is however not constructive.

This has a variety of applications in non standard logics and proofs such as quantitative logics or cyclic proofs.

---

I am a bit unsure about the placement of certain theorems, namely:
-  The placement of the `limitation` definition and its theorems. This feels very special to this theorem. Thus I left it in this file. It could however also live somewhere in Ordinals/Cardinals
- The theorems `monotone_stabilizing` and  `antitone_stabilizing`. I first thought about placing them in `Mathlib.Order.Monotone.Basic`. However, `Monotone` is using preorders and not partialorders, where this theorem does not hold. Maybe this theorem is also already proven somewhere else and I missed it?
- The `OrdinalApprox` namespace could also live in `Mathlib.Order.FixedPoints`. However, I decided aginst it as this would mean that importing `Mathlib.Order.FixedPoints` would also import a lot of (likely unecessary) files from `Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal` and `Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal` when not using ordinal approximants.

I appreciate comments regarding these questions and reviews in general. I also appreciate a comment if this has already been done and I just totally missed it.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Thank you for the detailed comments! I am rather busy the next two weeks. But as soon as I get to it, I will incorporate or react to all comments. I am also still very motivated to finish up the PR.
I believe, I have addressed all issues. Please let me know if I missed anything.

Thank you for the review and don't worry about the delay.

I have changed the documentation to only communicate the approximation scheme and explain why it's not constructive (despite the name of the papers). If I missed anything, please let me know.

I also decided to remove Ordinal from the filename, as the filename was already very long. Please also let me know if you think this is confusing now (as e.g. the Kleene fixed-point theorem is not located there)

I will also resolve / comment on your detailed comments.

Can you move/rename the file to `Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/FixedPointApproximants.lean`? I think `Ordinal` is a better folder for this file (though I do not feel strongly about this), but the name `FixedPointApproximants` is a bit better than the current name.
Every suggestion should be incorporated.

Thank you for incorporating all review suggestions!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8629040110/job/23652375240)

Sorry for the delayed response here, @PhoenixIra. I don't know enough about the mathematics to judge whether this is the right thing to prove, but I can make suggestions about mathlib style, which you'll find below. Could you let us know whether you're still up for finishing this PR?

Sorry for the delayed response here, @PhoenixIra. I don't know enough about the mathematics to judge whether this is the right thing to prove, but I can make suggestions about mathlib style, which you'll find below. Could you let us know whether you're still up for finishing this PR?

Hi! Sorry that this has been in review limbo for a while. I'll try to be relatively responsive on this PR from now on.

I have some style and content comments below, but I also have some questions.
As mentioned below, your proof uses various non-constructive things (ordinals, the lemma `Injective.exists_ne_of_not_injective`, and other things), so I don't think you should claim that this proof is constructive. 
Also, you're not proving the Knaster–Tarski theorem, but only a subresult of that theorem. Lemma 1 from [Echenique2005], I believe? So please update the PR title/description + module doc + docstrings to reflect that.

Thanks for the changes.

I have a few more suggestions. If you incorporate those (and the same for `gfp`, then I'm happy to merge this.
I don't think this name expresses the statement well. Maybe `exists_ne_of_not_injective`? Better suggestions welcome
Please use `simp?` and commit the output
I think you should just inline this where you use it. (Otherwise I'd call it `le_gfp_of_eq`.)
I removed it, as I am not using it any more.

```suggestion
theorem not_isMax (ℵ : Cardinal) : ¬ IsMax ℵ := by
```

```suggestion
  unfold IsMax at h
  specialize h (cantor ℵ).le
```

```suggestion
theorem succ_lt (ℵ : Cardinal) : ℵ < succ ℵ := Order.lt_succ_of_not_isMax (not_isMax ℵ)
```
Could you add pointers to reference works or papers that cover these subjects?

```suggestion
/-- Limitation of an ordinal defined function to an initial segment -/
```

```suggestion
def limitation : { i : Ordinal // i < (ord <| succ #α) } → α := fun i => g i
```

```suggestion
theorem limitation_def (i : { i : Ordinal // i < (ord <| succ #α) }) : limitation g i = g i := rfl
```

```suggestion
lemma mk_initialSeg_subtype (ℵ : Cardinal) : #{ i : Ordinal // i < (ord  ℵ) } = lift.{u+1, u} ℵ := by
```

I think
```suggestion
theorem not_injective_limitation : ¬ Injective (limitation g) := by
```
These seem like they could go somewhere earlier; try `#find_home`. Probably they could also be named to allow dot notation (i.e. `Monotone.stabilizing`)
This could go into the module header; also add to `docs/references.bib`
When you merge master, you'll notice that this syntax has changed recently.
Make sure to use `·` to demarcate different subgoals

```suggestion
def lfpApproxHom : Ordinal.{u} →o α where
```
I removed this as it was not necessary for any of the theorems.
Squeeze all non-terminal `simp`s
There should not be a need to end a line with a semicolon. Please remove them in the entire PR

```suggestion
    ∀ b > a, lfp_approx f b ∈ fixedPoints f := by
```

Presumably
```suggestion
/-- If there are distinct ordinals with equal value then the values are fixed points of f -/
```

```suggestion
  every value following the smaller ordinal are fixed points of -/
```

```suggestion
  obtain rfl | h_ia := eq_or_ne i a
```

```suggestion
  cases le_total a b with
```

```suggestion
    exact lfp_approx_many_fixedPoints f b a (h_nab.symm.lt_of_le h_ba)
```
least?
Seems like a lot of repeated code after this. Maybe there's a clever way to avoid it?
I use now the order homomorphism duality.

**[lint-bib]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion @Article{ CousotCousot1979, ```

**[lint-bib]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion year = 1979 ```

**[lint-bib]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```

**[lint-bib]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```

**[lint-bib]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion title = {A short and constructive proof of Tarski’s fixed-point theorem}, ```

**[lint-bib]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion @Book{ egno15, ```

```suggestion
theorem not_injective_iff : ¬ Injective f ↔ ∃ a b, a ≠ b ∧ f a = f b := by
  simp only [Injective, not_forall, exists_prop, and_comm]
```
Pleas make an iff, and improve name

Please rename to `Monotone.eq_of_le_of_le` or something. `stabilizing` is not a good name.

Please state inequalities using `≤`. It's also good to just add all hypotheses as arguments (not have any `∀` left in the conclusion), and make arguments that occur in hypothesis implicit (also below).
```suggestion
theorem Monotone.eq_of_le_of_le {a₁ a₂ : α} (h_mon : Monotone f) (h_fa : f a₁ = f a₂) {i : α} 
    (h1 : a₁ ≤ i) (h2 : i ≤ a₂) : f i = f a₁ := by
```
Please make the same changes to the `Antitone` version.

```suggestion
  · rw [h_fa]; exact h_mon h₂
```
Please also do this for the other 14 occurrences of `rw[`.

```suggestion
variable (g : Ordinal → α)
```
Please also add a space in all occurrences of `x:` and `h:` below.

Optional: Instead of defining a new function, could you state this as `¬ Set.InjOn g (Set.Iio (ord (succ #α)))` (and `open Set` to make it shorter)? That should avoid some annoyances with using subtypes.

```suggestion
theorem lfpApprox_add_one (a : Ordinal.{u}) : lfpApprox f (a+1) = f (lfpApprox f a) := by
```

Please make `a` and `b` implicit (also in other lemmas, if they occur in at least one hypothesis). Rename to something like `lpfApprox_eq_of_mem_fixedPoints`. Also change `b > a` to `a ≤ b` (that also simplifies your proof).
Do you really think this is worth a lemma? The proof is just `rwa [lfpApprox_stabilizing_at_fixedPoint f a h b h_ab]` after the intros.
use `lfpApprox_monotone` here

```suggestion
/-- If there are distinct ordinals with equal value then
```
(also elsewhere)
I would remove this lemma, and inline its proof in the next lemma (the proof of the next lemma should become trivial after weakening the inequality in `lpfApprox_eq_of_mem_fixedPoints`)
rename to `lfpApprox_mem_fixedPoints` or `lfpApprox_mem_fixedPoints_of_eq` or something.

Our cardinals and ordinals are not at all constructive, so I don't think you should claim that this is constructive. Furthermore, it is also not Knaster-Tarski Theorem, since you're only approximating the least (and greatest) fixed points.
Optional: It might be useful to add an extra argument `x : α`, and have `lfpApprox 0 x = x`. Then you can use this to approximate other fixed points than just the first one.

I see why this is useful. However, when trying to adapt it, some problems occurred to me there.
- There are multiple ways to formalize it, which behave differently:
  1.   `| 0 => x | Succ a => f (approx f x a) | limit A => sSup A`
     This formalization still satisfies `lfpApprox_add_one`, but not `lfpApprox_monotone`
  2. `sSup ({ f (lfpApprox x b) | (b : Ordinal) (h : b < a) } ∪ {x}`
     This formalization still satisfies `lfpApprox_monotone`, but not `lfpApprox_add_one`
 
  I'd argue that the person who formalizes approximation schemes for the next fixed points should decide how to formalize it. 
- Since not both `lfpApprox_add_one` and `lfpApprox_monotone` holds at the same time, nearly all other proofs will not work. I am also not sure, which condition is required for either of the formalizations to hold again (but probably the existence of a next fixed point). Then I feel like this parameter could be misleading as it suggests existence of theorems involving it. 

That's why I would opt to not include the extra argument in the current PR.

That's fair, there are indeed some problems with starting at other values. However, you can assume that `x <= f x`, in which case you the two definitions should coincide, and you should be able to prove everything (and then `gfpApprox` characterizes the other case, where `f x <= x`).
You are right. I changed it accordingly (and decided then on formalization ii) and everywhere where it makes sense (i.e. when not using `lfp`/`gfp`), it is now used with an initial value.

```suggestion
theorem lfpApprox_le_fixedPoint : ∀ a ∈ fixedPoints f, ∀ i : Ordinal, lfpApprox f i ≤ a := by
```
That will also make it easier to apply it

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (h₁ : a₁ ≤ i) (h₂ : i ≤ a₂) : f i = f a₁ := by ```

```suggestion
      #(Iio (ord <| succ #α)) = lift (succ #α) := by
```
I think you can remove all universe hints in this file, except the ones in the definitions of `lfpApprox` and `gfpApprox`.

```suggestion
theorem lfpApprox_eq_of_mem_fixedPoints {a b : Ordinal.{u}} (h_ab : a ≤ b)
```

```suggestion
    · rw [IH a' ha'b (le_of_not_lt haa), h]
```
the case analysis is not necessary

```suggestion
theorem exists_lfpApprox_eq_lfpApprox : ∃ a < ord <| succ #α, ∃ b < ord <| succ #α,
```

```suggestion
theorem lfpApprox_ord_mem_fixedPoints : lfpApprox f (ord <| succ #α) ∈ fixedPoints f := by
```

```suggestion
theorem lfpApprox_le_of_mem_fixedPoints {a : α} (h_a : a ∈ fixedPoints f) (i : Ordinal) :
```

```suggestion
theorem lfpApprox_ord_eq_lfp : lfpApprox f (ord <| succ #α) = lfp f := by
```

```suggestion
theorem exists_lfpApprox_eq_lfp : ∃ a : Ordinal, lfpApprox f a = lfp f := by
```

Actually, this is a better way of stating this (same proof works):
```suggestion
theorem lfp_mem_range_lfpApprox : lfp f ∈ Set.range (lfpApprox f) := by
```
Can you remove all files that are transitively imported?

```suggestion
theorem le_lfpApprox {a : Ordinal}: x ≤ lfpApprox f x a := by
```
Otherwise than this, LGTM

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Ordinal Approximants of the least/greatest fixed point in a complete lattice
